Award.AwardTitle: New probes of cosmological initial conditions and dark matter properties
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Daniel Grin is awarded an NSF Astronomy and Astrophysics Postdoctoral Fellowship to carry out a program of research and education at the University of Chicago. About one quarter of the Universe consists of an unknown constituent that astrophysicists have given the term "dark matter." Because this dark matter is all around us and has a profound effect upon the Universe, physicists seek to understand its nature and ultimately seek its true identity.

The Fellow will conduct a theoretic study that addresses two unusual dark matter (DM) candidates: an extremely light axion (ELA) and a sterile neutrino. The ELA is motivated by string theory, the sterile neutrino by problems with Lambda Cold Dark Matter theory and by the non-zero neutrino mass. The Fellow will test these new DM candidates with observables, connect these ideas to the established CMB anisotropy experimental program and the spectral distortion frontier, and better connect atomic physics to the thermalization epoch. The Fellow will test homogeneity of the baryon fraction and improve understanding of non-Gaussian estimators with implications for early universe physics. This project will produce knowledge about the constituents of the universe and their fluctuations.

The broader impacts of this project include a significant educational component. The Fellow will undertake a new outreach effort for senior citizens in underserved areas of Chicago, where opportunities for lifelong learning are few. The Fellow will create, manage, and present a new series of astronomy/cosmology classes in cooperation with senior centers of the Chicago Area Agency on Aging, reaching more than about 200 seniors a year. Classes will be free, taught by young scientists, and will appeal to many learning styles. The major objective of this work is to introduce modern research in astronomy/cosmology to underserved Chicago senior citizens.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI and collaborators developed new computational tools to understand dark matter/dark energy, analyzed data, and developed theoretical insights into the problems of dark matter and dark energy. The PI and collaborators created a new outreach program to older adults throughout Chicago, bringing science content to hundreds of older adults, and training academic staff at all levels in effective communication techniques to diverse audiences.

 

INTELLECTUAL MERIT:

The cosmic microwave background is the thermal afterglow of the hot big bang. By measuring small fluctuations in maps of it, we can learn about the mysterious physics of the dark matter and dark energy dominating the universe today. Similar insights follow by looking at the large-scale structure of galaxy today.

In this work, the PI and collaborators developed computational tools to search for ultra-light axions (a hypothetical candidate for the dark matter or dark energy in the universe), and applied them to measurements of the cosmic microwave background and spatial distribution of galaxies. As a result, some of the tightest and most reliable limits to axion parameter space were obtained. The promise of future experiments to further probe the axion parameter space was also assessed, as were the implications of ultra-light axions and inflationary gravitational waves for each other. One key finding is that the detection of ultra-light axions in the lab would make a detection of primordial gravitational waves in the CMB unlikely, and conversely that a detection of primordial gravitational waves in the CMB would really squeeze the ultra-light axion parameter space. 

 

To obtain these results, the PI and collaborators created a publicly available version of their code axionCAMB which is available to the community for analysis of other data on the website GITHUB.

 

An independent track of the work was a detailed exploration of how entropy fluctuations are generated by additional particle species in the very early universe, and how they might be detected. The PI and collaborators showed that well-motivated models could be detected, built the relevant statistical tools, ran simulations to determine confounding effects that could bias the results, and analyzed existing cosmic microwave background data to look for such effects and put limits on these models. One key finding was that gravitational lensing of the cosmic microwave background needs to be taken into account, and that the smallest scale entropy fluctuations between baryons and dak matter can only be detected if they themselves are on length scales that project onto a degree scale on the sky when the cosmic microwave background is produced. Another key finding was the early-universe models (called the curvaton models) that agree with current data could be decisively tested by future cosmic microwave background and large-scale structure experiments

 

BROADER IMPACTS:

I created an outreach program for older adults throughout Chicago. The program consisted of cycles of 4-6 hourlong talks on many topics (including stars, cosmology, galaxies, exoplanets, dark matter, dark energy, supernovae, gravitational waves, and biology topics), delivered to audiences of older adults at Chicago Area Agency on Aging senior centers, residential facilities, and public libraries. Over 3 years, we gave 100 presentations to 2315 audience members (231 unique), and conducted 8 field trips to the Adler planetarium for 185 of our students. We had 37 unique presenters.

I gave talks, organized the program, cultivated/maintained relationships with venues, recruited/trained speakers, coordinated site logistics, collated and collected past presentations, organized the training, and presented results of our work at UChicago presentations and the annual American Society on Aging conference.  Presenters were trained by a professional gerontologist (K. Flude), whose advice drove expanded our reach from senior centers to public libraries, hubs for many older adults who eschew the "senior citizen" label but wish to stay active. Flude gave 4 trainings for presenters throughout the  program, teaching our speakers effective presentation strategies for older audiences. 

The program was acclaimed and grew to include inter-generational audiences (and thus building new connections/bridges). We were asked back to all locations. Collaborating with an external assessor, we found that participants overwhelmingly enjoyed the lectures, learned a lot, were surprised at their enjoyment of a challenging topic, and loved connecting with our speakers (graduate students, postdocs, and faculty members at U Chicago). Just to give a taste, audience members reported that "It was all quite interesting and fascinating, very enjoyable" and that presenters were "Masterful storytellers. Better than any science fiction." 

The Kavli Institute for Cosmological Physics (at UChicago) is now maintaining and expanding this program as a signature effort, building partnerships with new older adult-serving institutions on Chicago's underserved South Side, and recruiting new speakers.
